questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for auricular hematoma to prevent recurrence and complications?

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman from a tropical region presents with complaints of intense itching, discomfort, and watery discharge from her right ear. questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with facial paralysis, vesicular rash on the pinna and external auditory canal, as shown in the picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following statements about malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is FALSE?

options.label: C
options.text: Radical surgery is the primary treatment for malignant otitis externa.

options.label: D
options.text: Antibiotic treatment for malignant otitis externa typically includes quinolones or third-generation cephalosporins.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a history of progressive bilateral hearing loss that began in her late twenties. She reports that she hears better in noisy environments. options.text: Sodium fluoride therapy to stabilize bone metabolism

questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with hearing loss and a sensation of ear fullness in the right ear. Otoscopic examination reveals the findings shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoes tympanoplasty for chronic otitis media with significant hearing loss. questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the surgical retractor depicted in the image:
questions.explanation:

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He is conscious but complains of headache and dizziness. Physical examination reveals bruising behind the left ear, as shown in the image. There is no obvious external bleeding. Which of the following is the most likely associated injury?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Temporal bone fracture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Battle's sign, bruising behind the ear, is a clinical hallmark of basilar skull fracture, most commonly involving the temporal bone.
  • ➤ basilar skull fracture, most commonly involving the temporal bone.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss in the right ear for the past year. Pure tone audiometry (PTA) findings are shown in the image. The air conduction curve shows a significant drop, while the bone conduction curve is within normal limits. The air-bone gap is greater than 20 dB. What type of hearing loss is indicated by the findings?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Conductive hearing loss

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conductive hearing loss is characterized by elevated air conduction thresholds, normal bone conduction thresholds, and a significant air-bone gap on pure tone audiometry.
  • ➤ elevated air conduction thresholds, normal bone conduction thresholds, and a significant air-bone gap on pure tone audiometry.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is the As tympanogram typically seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Otosclerosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

options.text: D. Begins in the 3rd week, completes in the 26th week

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with progressive hearing loss and tinnitus in his right ear. Neurological examination reveals reduced corneal reflex on the right side. Audiometry shows asymmetric hearing loss, and brainstem auditory evoked response (ABR) is performed. Which of the following findings would most likely indicate a retrocochlear lesion, such as an acoustic neuroma?

options.label: B
options.text: Prolonged interwave latency between wave I and wave V

options.label: D
options.text: Reduced amplitude of all waves bilaterally

questions.correct_answer: B. Prolonged interwave latency between wave I and wave V
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Prolonged interwave latency between wave I and wave V

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In brainstem auditory evoked response (ABR), prolonged interwave latency between wave I and wave V is a key finding in retrocochlear pathology, such as acoustic neuroma.
  • ➤ prolonged interwave latency between wave I and wave V is a key finding in retrocochlear pathology, such as acoustic neuroma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient was advised following test which showed that the SP/AP ratio is found to be greater than 30%, as shown in the graph. Which of the following audiometry is ossibly related to the same patient ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ménière's disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An elevated SP/AP ratio (>30%) on electrocochleography is indicative of Ménière's disease, a condition characterized by endolymphatic hydrops, episodic vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus.

questions.text: A patient with post traumatic facial nerve palsy has presented with absent taste sensation on anterior 2/3 rd part of his tongue. His stapedial reflex was checked and it was absent. Schirmer’s test for lacrimation was done and it was negative .i.e., lacrimation was normal. Most probable site of facial nerve lesion could be at

options.label: A
options.text: Translabyrinthine portion (the portion of facial nerve lying at the level of inner ear)

options.label: B
options.text: Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear

options.label: C
options.text: Vertical portion of facial nerve on the posterior wall of middle ear

options.label: D
options.text: In the parotid substance where it divides into its 5 terminal branches

questions.correct_answer: B. Horizontal portion of facial nerve on the medial wall of middle ear
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Horizontal portion of the facial nerve on the medial wall of the middle ear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lesion in the horizontal portion of the facial nerve on the medial wall of the middle ear causes loss of taste (via chorda tympani) and absent stapedial reflex (via nerve to stapedius), while preserving lacrimation (greater petrosal nerve exits proximal to this site).
  • ➤ horizontal portion of the facial nerve on the medial wall of the middle ear

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is known to cause conductive hearing loss?

questions.text: Tullio phenomenon (sound-induced vertigo) can be seen in all of the following conditions except:

questions.text: Why is sialolithiasis most commonly observed in the submandibular gland?

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with unilateral hardness of hearing and ear block sensation. Rinne was negative on affected side. Cone of light was absent and handle of malleus was foreshortened. On impedance audiometry, which of the following type of curve is most likely to appear ?

questions.text: A 3-month-old child was brought to an ENT consultant. Antenatal history revealed TORCH infection in the mother. The child was born at 32 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 1.5 kg, required 5 days of ventilation due to respiratory distress, and had pathological jaundice. On otoscopy, the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane appeared normal, and impedance audiometry showed a Type A curve. What is the first investigation you would advise for this child?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ In high-risk neonates (e.g., NICU stay ≥5 days, TORCH infection, hyperbilirubinemia), the first screening test for hearing loss should be Automated ABR (AABR), as it can detect both cochlear and retrocochlear pathologies, including auditory neuropathy.
  • ➤ In high-risk neonates (e.g., NICU stay ≥5 days, TORCH infection, hyperbilirubinemia), the first screening test for hearing loss should be Automated ABR (AABR), as it can detect both cochlear and retrocochlear pathologies, including auditory neuropathy.

questions.text: Regarding the drainage of the paranasal sinuses, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Maxillary sinus drains into the inferior meatus

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior ethmoid air cells drain into the superior meatus

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are false

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the correct drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses:
  • ➤ Maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus . Anterior ethmoid air cells drain into the middle meatus . Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the superior meatus . Sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess .
  • ➤ Maxillary sinus drains into the middle meatus .
  • ➤ Maxillary sinus
  • ➤ middle meatus
  • ➤ Anterior ethmoid air cells drain into the middle meatus .
  • ➤ Anterior ethmoid air cells
  • ➤ middle meatus
  • ➤ Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the superior meatus .
  • ➤ Posterior ethmoid air cells
  • ➤ superior meatus
  • ➤ Sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess .
  • ➤ Sphenoid sinus
  • ➤ sphenoethmoidal recess

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with unilateral hearing loss. Oto-endoscopic examination is shown. Rinne's test is negative on the affected ear, and Weber's test lateralizes to the same ear. Clinically, the next structure to be observed is:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with hearing loss. On testing, the following results are observed: Speech discrimination score: Very poor Roll-over phenomenon: Present Recruitment: Absent SISI score: 10% Tone decay: > 25 dB BERA: Abnormal What is the most likely site of the lesion?

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An Auditory Brainstem Implant (ABI) is indicated in cases where the cochlear nerve is non-functional, such as bilateral acoustic neuromas in NF2.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with clear, watery nasal discharge that worsens on bending forward or straining. He has a history of head trauma 4 weeks ago. The fluid tests positive for beta-2 transferrin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CSF Rhinorrhea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CSF rhinorrhea should be suspected in patients with clear nasal discharge, especially after head trauma, and confirmed by testing for beta-2 transferrin, a CSF-specific marker.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustains multiple facial injuries following a road traffic accident. On CT imaging, the fracture is noted to involve the lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, and pterygoid plates. Which type of Le Fort fracture is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Le Fort I

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Le Fort I fractures involve a transverse line through the lower nasal septum, maxillary antra, and pterygoid plates, resulting in a "floating palate."

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a nasal mass, epistaxis, and progressive swelling of the right cheek. Examination reveals loss of sensation over the cheek and proptosis in the right eye. Imaging shows a tumor involving the maxillary sinus and extending above Ohngren’s line. What is the most likely histological type of the tumor, and what is the appropriate management?

options.label: A
options.text: Adenocarcinoma; Endoscopic excision followed by chemotherapy

options.label: B
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma; Total maxillectomy and radiotherapy

options.label: D
options.text: Melanoma; Wide local excision and immunotherapy

questions.correct_answer: B. Squamous cell carcinoma; Total maxillectomy and radiotherapy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Squamous cell carcinoma; Total maxillectomy and radiotherapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Maxillary sinus tumors above Ohngren’s line have a poor prognosis and are often squamous cell carcinomas requiring total maxillectomy with radiotherapy.

questions.text: A 65-year-old diabetic woman, recently treated for COVID-19 with steroids and remdesivir, presents with nasal blockage and blackish, foul-smelling nasal discharge. Examination reveals a necrotic mass in the nasal cavity with erosion of the nasal septum and hard palate. What is the best next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Begin amphotericin B therapy and obtain a tissue biopsy

options.label: B
options.text: Start broad-spectrum antibiotics and nasal decongestants

options.label: C
options.text: Prescribe oral antifungal therapy and observe

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate surgical removal without further workup

questions.correct_answer: A. Begin amphotericin B therapy and obtain a tissue biopsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Begin amphotericin B therapy and obtain a tissue biopsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis in post-COVID-19 patients treated with steroids presents with black necrotic nasal tissue; management includes amphotericin B and tissue biopsy followed by surgical debridement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis, and a visible mass in the nasal cavity as shown in the image. CT scan demonstrates a locally invasive lesion. Histopathological examination reveals inward growth of epithelial tissue consistent with the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inverted papilloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inverted papilloma is a benign but locally aggressive sinonasal tumor characterized by inward epithelial growth, presenting with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Early diagnosis and surgical excision are crucial to prevent recurrence and potential malignant transformation.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male from a rural area presents with complaints of a polypoidal mass in the nasal cavity, nasal obstruction, and recurrent episodes of bleeding from the nose. Examination reveals a red, friable mass with a granular surface in the nasal cavity. Histopathology confirms the presence of sporangia containing endospores. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic granulomatous infection caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, presenting as a red, friable nasal mass with sporangia-containing endospores on histopathology.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from a low socioeconomic area presents with nasal obstruction, crusting, and nasal discharge. Examination reveals a hard, nodular mass in the nasal cavity. Biopsy shows characteristic Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rhinoscleroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, characterized by hard nodular masses in the nasal cavity, with histological findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of recurrent sneezing, nasal congestion, and clear nasal discharge. She denies fever, itching, or eye redness. Symptoms worsen in cold weather and are not related to allergens or seasonal changes. On examination, the nasal mucosa appears pale and boggy. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vasomotor rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vasomotor rhinitis is a non-allergic condition characterized by nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and sneezing triggered by irritants or environmental changes, without the involvement of allergens or systemic symptoms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of chronic nasal obstruction, crusting, and foul-smelling nasal discharge. She complains of anosmia and frequent nosebleeds. On examination, the nasal cavity appears wide with atrophic mucosa and thick crusts. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Atrophic rhinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic condition characterized by atrophic nasal mucosa, crusting, foul-smelling discharge, widened nasal cavities, and anosmia.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with profuse nasal bleeding from the right nostril. He reports no recent trauma. On examination, the bleeding appears to originate from the posterior nasal cavity. Despite initial packing of the anterior nasal cavity, the bleeding persists. What is the next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Ligation of the external carotid artery

options.label: C
options.text: Endoscopic cauterization of the sphenopalatine artery

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Posterior nasal packing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior nasal packing is the next step in the management of posterior epistaxis when anterior packing fails, with surgical or endoscopic interventions reserved for refractory cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ENT clinic with recurrent episodes of nasal bleeding that usually stop spontaneously. He denies any trauma or anticoagulant use. On anterior rhinoscopy, bleeding is localized to the anterior part of the nasal septum. Which of the following anatomical structures is most likely involved in this patient’s condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Kiesselbach’s plexus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kiesselbach’s plexus in Little’s area is the most common site for anterior epistaxis due to its rich vascular anastomosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man begins choking while eating in a restaurant. Bystanders note that he is unable to speak or cough and appears to be in severe respiratory distress. A person trained in first aid attempts the maneuver shown in the image below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this maneuver?

options.label: A
options.text: Compression of the trachea to dislodge the obstruction

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure to expel the foreign body

options.label: D
options.text: Forced inspiration to bypass the obstruction

questions.correct_answer: B. Increase in intrathoracic pressure to expel the foreign body
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increase in intrathoracic pressure to expel the foreign body

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Heimlich maneuver expels a foreign body obstructing the airway by creating a sudden increase in intrathoracic pressure through abdominal thrusts applied below the diaphragm.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department following blunt trauma to the nose during a soccer game. On examination, his nasal dorsum appears swollen, and he complains of nasal obstruction and tenderness. On anterior rhinoscopy, a fluctuant, reddish swelling is noted on both sides of the nasal septum. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate incision and drainage with antibiotic coverage

options.label: C
options.text: Apply ice packs and schedule follow-up in 48 hours

options.label: D
options.text: Perform nasal packing and discharge the patient

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate incision and drainage with antibiotic coverage
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate incision and drainage with antibiotic coverage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Septal hematomas require urgent incision and drainage to prevent complications such as infection, cartilage necrosis, and saddle nose deformity, with appropriate antibiotic coverage to prevent secondary infections.

questions.text: Identify the cell marked with a “down arrow” in the CT images shown below.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Onodi cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Onodi cells are posterior ethmoid air cells located near the optic nerve and sphenoid sinus, making them clinically significant due to the risk of optic nerve injury during surgical procedures.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a neck swelling that becomes more prominent when he coughs or performs a Valsalva maneuver. He also reports intermittent hoarseness of voice. Examination reveals a soft, compressible swelling in the anterior neck that reduces with pressure. CT of the neck shows an air-filled sac communicating with the laryngeal ventricle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laryngocele

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngocele is an air-filled dilation of the saccule of the laryngeal ventricle, presenting as a neck swelling that becomes prominent with coughing or straining and may cause hoarseness.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with hoarseness of voice following thyroid surgery. On examination, there is evidence of vocal cord paralysis. Which of the following muscles is responsible for abducting the vocal cords?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posterior cricoarytenoid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The posterior cricoarytenoid is the only muscle responsible for abduction of the vocal cords, facilitating breathing by opening the glottis.
  • ➤ posterior cricoarytenoid
  • ➤ abduction

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with hoarseness of voice and difficulty in phonation following thyroid surgery. On examination, there is unilateral vocal cord paralysis. Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding the innervation of the larynx?

options.label: A
options.text: The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) innervates the cricothyroid muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more susceptible to injury due to its longer course.

options.label: C
options.text: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (EBSLN) provides sensory innervation to the larynx below the vocal cords.

options.label: D
options.text: The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (IBSLN) supplies motor innervation to all intrinsic laryngeal muscles.

questions.correct_answer: B. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more susceptible to injury due to its longer course.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more susceptible to injury due to its longer course.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more susceptible to injury due to its longer course around the aortic arch, leading to vocal cord paralysis in cases of damage.
  • ➤ left recurrent laryngeal nerve

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a hoarse voice and difficulty swallowing three weeks after thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopy reveals one vocal cord in an intermediate (cadaveric) position, 3.5 mm away from the midline. What is the most likely associated finding?

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of sensation above the vocal cords

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Weak and breathy voice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In unilateral vocal cord palsy , the affected vocal cord rests in the cadaveric position, leading to a breathy voice due to incomplete glottic closure during phonation.
  • ➤ unilateral vocal cord palsy

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with acute onset respiratory distress following thyroid surgery. Laryngoscopy reveals bilateral vocal cords in a paramedian position, with only a 3 mm gap between them during inspiration. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Emergency tracheostomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy , emergency tracheostomy is the immediate management to secure the airway, while definitive procedures like arytenoidectomy or lateralization are considered for long-term treatment.
  • ➤ bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

questions.text: The below image displays sequential laryngeal pathologies. Identify the corresponding causal factors in sequence:

options.label: A
options.text: Professional voice use, vocal abuse, smoking, prolonged endotracheal intubation

options.label: B
options.text: Smoking, prolonged endotracheal intubation, professional voice use, vocal abuse

options.label: C
options.text: Professional voice use, prolonged endotracheal intubation, vocal abuse, smoking

options.label: D
options.text: Smoking, professional voice use, vocal abuse, prolonged endotracheal intubation

questions.correct_answer: A. Professional voice use, vocal abuse, smoking, prolonged endotracheal intubation
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Professional voice use, vocal abuse, smoking, prolonged endotracheal intubation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the sequential causal factors for specific laryngeal pathologies, correlating professional voice use, vocal abuse, smoking, and prolonged endotracheal intubation with nodules, polyps, reinke edema and granulomas respectively.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl presents with fever, severe throat pain, drooling, and difficulty breathing. She prefers sitting in a tripod position and has a muffled "hot potato" voice. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what should be the immediate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Acute epiglottitis; prepare for airway stabilization and administer IV antibiotics

options.label: C
options.text: Retropharyngeal abscess; perform CT neck and start IV antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: Croup; administer nebulized epinephrine and steroids

questions.correct_answer: B. Acute epiglottitis; prepare for airway stabilization and administer IV antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute epiglottitis; prepare for airway stabilization and administer IV antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute epiglottitis is a medical emergency characterized by drooling, tripod position, and muffled voice. Immediate airway stabilization and IV antibiotics are critical to prevent life-threatening airway obstruction.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a history of fever, a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor that worsens at night. His oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. What is the next best step in management?

options.label: C
options.text: Perform a lateral neck X-ray to confirm diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Administer nebulized epinephrine and corticosteroids
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Administer nebulized epinephrine and corticosteroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Croup is a viral infection causing a barking cough, inspiratory stridor, and hoarseness. Treatment includes nebulized epinephrine for airway edema and corticosteroids for reducing inflammation, with intubation reserved for severe cases.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with a history of hoarseness and worsening difficulty breathing over several months. Flexible laryngoscopy reveals multiple papillomatous lesions in the larynx. The child has no history of recent infections, fever, or systemic illness. What is the most likely etiology of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recurrent respiratory papillomatosis is caused by HPV (types 6 and 11), leading to benign papillomatous growths in the larynx, primarily presenting with hoarseness, stridor, or airway obstruction in children.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic with noisy breathing that started shortly after birth and worsens when the child is crying, feeding, or lying supine. The parents report no cyanosis or fever. Physical examination reveals inspiratory stridor without signs of respiratory distress. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Laryngomalacia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of congenital inspiratory stridor, which worsens with supine positioning and improves spontaneously as the infant grows. It results from the collapse of the supraglottic structures during inspiration.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with hoarseness of voice for 6 months and difficulty swallowing for 3 weeks. On examination, there is vocal cord fixation, and imaging reveals a tumor extending into the pre-epiglottic space but sparing the thyroid cartilage. No cervical lymphadenopathy or distant metastasis is found. What is the correct staging, and what is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: B
options.text: Stage II, treated with conservation surgery

options.label: C
options.text: Stage III, treated with chemoradiation (CT + RT)

options.label: D
options.text: Stage IVa, treated with total laryngectomy + radiotherapy

questions.correct_answer: C. Stage III, treated with chemoradiation (CT + RT)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Stage III, treated with chemoradiation (CT + RT)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stage III laryngeal cancer (T3 N0 M0 or T1-3 N1 M0) involves vocal cord fixation or invasion of the pre-epiglottic space and is treated primarily with chemoradiation for organ preservation. Total laryngectomy is reserved for non-responders or more advanced stages.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male underwent total laryngectomy for advanced laryngeal cancer. He is now seeking rehabilitation to restore his ability to speak. He prefers a method that provides clear speech with the least effort. Which of the following is the most appropriate option for him?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Tracheo-oesophageal speech

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tracheo-oesophageal speech using prostheses like the Blom-Singer valve or Provox is the most effective post-laryngectomy speech rehabilitation technique, providing the best clarity and ease of use.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male presents with progressive dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food, and a sensation of a lump in the throat. He reports bad breath and occasional choking episodes. Barium swallow shows an outpouching at the posterior pharyngoesophageal junction. What is the primary management for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Botulinum toxin injection into the upper esophageal sphincter

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cricopharyngeal myotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The primary treatment for Zenker's diverticulum is cricopharyngeal myotomy, which addresses the underlying hypertrophy or dysfunction of the cricopharyngeus muscle.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with a fever, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a muffled voice. Examination reveals neck swelling and tenderness, with the child holding their neck in slight hyperextension. Lateral neck X-ray shows prevertebral soft tissue swelling. What is the next best step in the management of this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Perform needle aspiration under CT guidance

options.label: C
options.text: Immediate surgical drainage and intravenous antibiotics

options.label: D
options.text: Start high-dose corticosteroids to reduce inflammation

questions.correct_answer: C. Immediate surgical drainage and intravenous antibiotics
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Immediate surgical drainage and intravenous antibiotics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of retropharyngeal abscess involves immediate surgical drainage and intravenous antibiotics to prevent life-threatening complications such as airway obstruction and mediastinal extension.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with persistent nasal obstruction, mouth breathing, and snoring. The parents report a history of recurrent ear infections and difficulty hearing. Examination reveals a long-standing open-mouth posture and high-arched palate. What is the most likely complication if the condition is left untreated?

options.label: A
options.text: Chronic sinusitis and otitis media with effusion

questions.correct_answer: A. Chronic sinusitis and otitis media with effusion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chronic sinusitis and otitis media with effusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic adenoid hypertrophy can cause nasal obstruction, recurrent otitis media with effusion, and chronic sinusitis due to impaired drainage of the nasopharynx and Eustachian tube dysfunction.

questions.text: Identify the sequence of tonsillectomy instruments shown in the image.

options.label: A
options.text: Boyle Davis mouth gag, Eve tonsillar snare, Draffin bipods, Dennis Browne tonsil holding forceps

options.label: B
options.text: Dennis Browne tonsil holding forceps, Boyle Davis mouth gag, Draffin bipods, Eve tonsillar snare

options.label: C
options.text: Boyle Davis mouth gag, Dennis Browne tonsil holding forceps, Eve tonsillar snare, Draffin bipods

options.label: D
options.text: Draffin bipods, Boyle Davis mouth gag, Dennis Browne tonsil holding forceps, Eve tonsillar snare

questions.correct_answer: A. Boyle Davis mouth gag, Eve tonsillar snare, Draffin bipods, Dennis Browne tonsil holding forceps
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Boyle Davis mouth gag, Eve tonsillar snare, Draffin bipods, Dennis Browne tonsil holding forceps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand the sequence and function of instruments used in a tonsillectomy: Boyle Davis mouth gag for retraction, Draffin bipods for stabilization, Eve tonsillar snare for excision, and Dennis Browne forceps for holding the tonsils.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis. Examination reveals a pinkish, lobulated mass in the nasopharynx that does not bleed on touch. CT scan shows a mass with bony erosion of the posterior nasal cavity and extension into the pterygopalatine fossa. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma (JNA) is a vascular tumor of adolescent males presenting with nasal obstruction, recurrent epistaxis, and characteristic imaging findings of bony erosion and mass extension. Early diagnosis and staging are essential for proper management.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male from Southeast Asia presents with a 3-month history of nasal obstruction, blood-stained nasal discharge, and a sensation of fullness in the ear. Examination reveals a neck mass in the posterior cervical triangle. A biopsy of the nasopharyngeal mass shows poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most likely etiological factor associated with this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is strongly associated with Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) and commonly presents with nasal symptoms, hearing loss, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It is prevalent in Southeast Asia, and early diagnosis is critical for optimal management.

questions.text: Which of the following is part of Trotter's triad, commonly seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma?

options.label: A
options.text: Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

options.label: B
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

options.label: C
options.text: Sensorineural hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Conductive hearing loss, Contralateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

questions.correct_answer: A. Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Conductive hearing loss, Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, Palatal paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trotter's triad in nasopharyngeal carcinoma includes conductive hearing loss, ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia, and palatal paralysis, indicative of tumor invasion in the nasopharyngeal region.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with fever, severe throat pain, difficulty swallowing, and a muffled voice. On examination, there is trismus, uvular deviation to the right, and swelling of the left peritonsillar region. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Empirical antibiotics and close outpatient monitoring

options.label: B
options.text: Immediate incision and drainage of the peritonsillar abscess

options.label: C
options.text: CT scan of the neck to confirm the diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: B. Immediate incision and drainage of the peritonsillar abscess
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Immediate incision and drainage of the peritonsillar abscess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy), characterized by fever, trismus, uvular deviation, and peritonsillar swelling, the first-line treatment involves incision and drainage of the abscess, followed by antibiotic therapy to address the infection.

questions.text: The procedure shown in the image below is an indirect laryngoscopy. Which of the following statements about this procedure is true?

options.label: A
options.text: It is the investigation of choice for detecting subglottic stenosis.

options.label: B
options.text: It is contraindicated in patients with a strong gag reflex.

options.label: C
options.text: It provides a direct view of the vocal cords.

options.label: D
options.text: It is performed with a flexible fiberoptic laryngoscope.

questions.correct_answer: B. It is contraindicated in patients with a strong gag reflex.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is contraindicated in patients with a strong gag reflex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Indirect laryngoscopy is a quick, non-invasive procedure to visualize the larynx using a mirror but is contraindicated in patients with a strong gag reflex.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents with a sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and a white membrane over the tonsils. On examination, there is no bleeding upon scraping the membrane. Which of the following is not a likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diphtheria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphtheria is characterized by a grayish-white pseudomembrane that is firmly adherent to the tonsils and bleeds when scraped. Differentiating it from other causes of membranous tonsillitis is essential for prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with bleeding from the oral cavity 5 days after undergoing a tonsillectomy. On examination, blood clots are visible at the surgical site. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Shift to the operating theater (OT), remove the clots, and cauterize/ligate the vessel.

options.label: B
options.text: Admit the patient and start intravenous (IV) antibiotics.

options.label: C
options.text: Administer anticoagulants, encourage repeated gargling, and observe for 24 hours.

options.label: D
options.text: Perform a blood transfusion and adopt a wait-and-watch approach

questions.correct_answer: B. Admit the patient and start intravenous (IV) antibiotics.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Admit the patient and start intravenous (IV) antibiotics.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In secondary post-tonsillectomy hemorrhage, admission and IV antibiotics are the first steps in management to control infection and stabilize the patient. Surgical intervention is reserved for cases where bleeding persists despite initial treatment.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with the arrow in the given image.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Passavant's ridge

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Passavant's ridge is a pharyngeal structure that aids in velopharyngeal closure during swallowing or phonation, preventing regurgitation into the nasopharynx.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with difficulty in opening his mouth, a burning sensation while eating spicy food, and stiffening of the oral mucosa. He has a history of chewing betel quid and tobacco for 10 years. Examination reveals blanching of the buccal mucosa and fibrotic bands. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral submucous fibrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oral submucous fibrosis is a premalignant condition caused by areca nut or betel quid chewing, characterized by submucosal fibrosis, restricted mouth opening, and a burning sensation on eating spicy food.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female presents with a painless swelling in the floor of the mouth that has progressively increased in size over the past few weeks. On examination, the lesion is bluish, fluctuant, and non-tender, located lateral to the midline. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ranula

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A ranula is a mucus retention cyst arising from the sublingual gland or submandibular duct, presenting as a bluish, fluctuant swelling in the floor of the mouth, often lateral to the midline.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with fever, headache, and swelling in the parotid region bilaterally. On examination, the swelling is tender, firm, and extends to the angle of the mandible. The patient reports difficulty chewing and swallowing. He has not received any vaccinations. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mumps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mumps presents with bilateral parotid gland swelling, fever, and systemic symptoms, commonly in unvaccinated children, and can lead to complications such as orchitis, meningitis, and pancreatitis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a slow-growing, painless mass in the parotid gland. Fine-needle aspiration cytology reveals a biphasic tumor with epithelial and myoepithelial components embedded in a chondromyxoid stroma. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pleomorphic adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleomorphic adenoma is a benign salivary gland tumor characterized histologically by epithelial and myoepithelial components within a chondromyxoid stroma, while Warthin tumor is distinguished by papillary cystic structures and lymphoid stroma.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presents with a painful mass in the submandibular gland that has been growing for the past few months. She also reports numbness over the affected side of her face. Biopsy reveals a tumor composed of mucin-producing cells, squamous cells, and intermediate cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mucoepidermoid carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucoepidermoid carcinoma is a malignant salivary gland tumor with a mix of mucin-producing, intermediate, and squamous cells, often presenting with pain and nerve involvement, while adenoid cystic carcinoma is characterized by cribriform patterns and perineural invasion.

questions.text: The following coronal section of a CT scan of the paranasal sinuses (PNS) is taken at which level?

options.label: A
options.text: 1-1.5 cm behind the anterior end of the inferior turbinate

options.label: B
options.text: 1-1.5 cm behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate

options.label: C
options.text: 1-1.5 cm behind the posterior end of the middle turbinate

options.label: D
options.text: 1-1.5 cm behind the anterior end of the middle turbinate

questions.correct_answer: A. 1-1.5 cm behind the anterior end of the inferior turbinate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-1.5 cm behind the anterior end of the inferior turbinate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The nasolacrimal duct lies approximately 1.25 cm posterior to the anterior end of the inferior turbinate, as seen on coronal CT sections of the paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: Why is Dodd's sign absent in juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA)?

options.label: A
options.text: JNA arises from the posterior pharyngeal wall

options.label: B
options.text: JNA arises from the sphenopalatine foramen

options.label: C
options.text: JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin

options.label: D
options.text: JNA does not have a muscular contractile part in its blood vessels

questions.correct_answer: C. JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) JNA spreads submucosally from its point of origin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) spreads submucosally without mucosal involvement, explaining the absence of Dodd's sign.

questions.text: A patient underwent the procedure shown in the image and had a BERA test afterward, where the sound stimulus was directly delivered to the processor instead of the ear canal. Which waves are likely to be found abnormal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) I & II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ After an Auditory Brainstem Implant (ABI), waves I and II in BERA remain absent due to bypassing the auditory nerve, while waves III–VII generated by brainstem nuclei and auditory cortex are present.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with right-sided hearing difficulty. Otoendoscopy shows a reddish hue behind the tympanic membrane (Schwartz sign), and pure tone audiometry (PTA) reveals conductive hearing loss on the right. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the management of this patient?

options.label: C
options.text: Middle ear structures modified during surgery develop from the 1st pharyngeal arch

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Surgery is contraindicated

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Active otosclerosis with Schwartz sign is a contraindication for surgery due to increased vascularity and risk of bleeding. Surgery should only be performed during the inactive phase of the disease.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester complains of hearing her own breathing sounds. On otoscopic examination, the tympanic membrane is seen moving synchronously with respiration, and this movement becomes exaggerated when the contralateral nostril is occluded. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Patulous Eustachian tube

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patulous Eustachian tube is characterized by autophony and tympanic membrane movement synchronous with respiration. It is common in the third trimester of pregnancy and typically does not require treatment unless chronic or bothersome.

questions.text: Which of the following descriptions best fits cholesteatoma?

options.label: A
options.text: A cholesterol-containing tumor in the middle ear

options.label: B
options.text: Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative

options.label: C
options.text: Endodermal derivative in a space enclosed by ectodermal derivative

options.label: D
options.text: Mesodermal tissue proliferation in the middle ear

questions.correct_answer: B. Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ectodermal derivative in a space enclosed by endodermal derivative

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cholesteatoma is an ectodermal derivative (keratinizing squamous epithelium) abnormally located in a space normally lined by endodermal derivative (mucosal lining of the middle ear). This abnormality can lead to chronic infections and bony destruction.

questions.text: An ENT surgeon performing a singular neurectomy for intractable BPPV accidentally cuts its parent nerve. Which other structure is expected to lose its sensory supply in addition to the posterior semicircular canal?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Macula of saccule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The singular nerve is a branch of the inferior vestibular nerve and innervates the posterior semicircular canal and saccule. Damage to the inferior vestibular nerve affects sensory input from both these structures.

questions.text: A patient eating fish suddenly feels something stuck in her throat and comes to the ER with a pricking sensation. The X-ray is given below. What is the location of the foreign body?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) None

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fish bones often cause mucosal trauma without being visible on X-rays. Reassurance and symptomatic treatment are the key steps when no foreign body is seen.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about nystagmus?

options.label: A
options.text: It is an involuntary, rhythmical, oscillatory movement of eyes.

options.label: B
options.text: It may be horizontal, vertical, or rotatory.

options.label: C
options.text: Direction of nystagmus is indicated by the direction of the slow component.

options.label: D
options.text: Intensity of nystagmus is indicated by its degree.

questions.correct_answer: C. Direction of nystagmus is indicated by the direction of the slow component.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Direction of nystagmus is indicated by the direction of the slow component.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The direction of nystagmus is defined by the fast phase of the oscillatory eye movement, even though the slow phase represents the pathological component.
  • ➤ fast phase

questions.text: Nystagmus to the side of the lesion is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serous labyrinthitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Irritative labyrinthine lesions (e.g., serous labyrinthitis) cause nystagmus to the affected side, while paretic lesions (e.g., purulent labyrinthitis, VIII nerve section, labyrinthine trauma) cause nystagmus to the healthy side.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a history of right ear hearing loss and intermittent foul-smelling discharge for several years. On examination, a small perforation is noted in the pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: A
options.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks

options.label: B
options.text: Intravenous antibiotics and follow-up after a month

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Tympanomastoid exploration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Attico-antral disease with cholesteatoma requires tympanomastoid exploration to remove the disease and render the ear safe, prioritizing disease eradication over hearing preservation.

questions.text: A patient with chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) and central perforation reports hearing better when there is ear discharge than when the ear is dry. What is this phenomenon called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Round window shielding effect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "round window shielding effect" in patients with central perforation explains improved hearing with ear discharge by maintaining phase differential between the oval and round windows.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true regarding the pediatric eustachian tube?

options.label: A
options.text: It is shorter, wider, more horizontal

options.label: B
options.text: Density of elastin at the hinge is less

options.label: C
options.text: Ostmann’s pad of fat is less

options.label: D
options.text: Bony part is slightly less than one-third of the total length

questions.correct_answer: D. Bony part is slightly less than one-third of the total length
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bony part is slightly less than one-third of the total length

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The pediatric eustachian tube is shorter, more horizontal, has less elastin density, and a smaller Ostmann's pad of fat, with the bony part being slightly longer than one-third of its total length.

questions.text: Identify the structures in the given image of the organ of Corti.

options.label: A
options.text: 7 – Tectorial membrane, 8 – Stereocilia, 9 – Outer hair cells, 10 – Basilar membrane, 11 – Cochlear nerve fibres, 12 – Inner hair cells

options.label: B
options.text: 7 – Tectorial membrane, 8 – Stereocilia, 9 – Inner hair cells, 10 – Basilar membrane, 11 – Cochlear nerve, 12 – Outer hair cells

options.label: C
options.text: 7 – Basilar membrane, 8 – Stereocilia, 9 – Outer hair cells, 10 – Tectorial membrane, 11 – Cochlear nerve, 12 – Inner hair cells

options.label: D
options.text: 7 – Tectorial membrane, 8 – Stereocilia, 9 – Outer hair cells, 10 – Basilar membrane, 11 – Vestibular nerve fibres, 12 – Inner hair cells

questions.correct_answer: A. 7 – Tectorial membrane, 8 – Stereocilia, 9 – Outer hair cells, 10 – Basilar membrane, 11 – Cochlear nerve fibres, 12 – Inner hair cells
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 7 – Tectorial membrane, 8 – Stereocilia, 9 – Outer hair cells, 10 – Basilar membrane, 11 – Cochlear nerve fibres, 12 – Inner hair cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The organ of Corti, situated on the basilar membrane, contains hair cells (inner and outer), stereocilia, and the tectorial membrane, which together transduce sound energy into neural signals.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Rinne test results and their correlation with the air-bone gap?

options.label: A
options.text: A Rinne test equal or negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 20–30 dB.

options.label: B
options.text: A Rinne test negative for 256 and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 30–45 dB.

options.label: C
options.text: A Rinne test negative for all the three tuning forks of 256, 512, and 1024 Hz indicates air-bone gap of 45–60 dB.

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Rinne test, when performed with tuning forks of different frequencies, can help predict the air-bone gap in conductive hearing loss, with specific thresholds for 256 Hz (20–30 dB), 512 Hz (30–45 dB), and 1024 Hz (45–60 dB).
